source.name: City of San Jose Environmental Services
source.notes: Based on City of San Jose Environmental Services and SanJoseRecycles.org guidelines. Uses blue (recycling), green (organics), gray (garbage) carts. Cart tagging program monitors recycling quality.

materials.name: Plastic bottles and jugs
instructions: Empty and rinse
Leave caps on
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: San Jose asks residents to leave caps on plastic bottles
All rigid plastic bottles accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid
Don't crush bottles

materials.name: Plastic tubs and containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Rigid plastic tubs of all types accepted
commonMistakes: No styrofoam containers
No black plastic

materials.name: Hard plastic clamshells
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: San Jose specifically accepts hard plastic clamshells
Must be rigid plastic, not foam
commonMistakes: Don't include foam/styrofoam clamshells
Rinse out food residue

materials.name: Plastic egg cartons
instructions: Rinse if needed
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: San Jose specifically accepts plastic egg cartons in recycling
Foam egg cartons are NOT accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include styrofoam egg cartons; those go in trash
Make sure it's rigid plastic, not foam

materials.name: Frozen food trays
instructions: Rinse clean
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: San Jose specifically lists frozen food trays as recyclable
commonMistakes: Must be rinsed; no food residue
Don't include trays with heavy foil lining

materials.name: Cleaning product containers
instructions: Empty completely
Quick rinse
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: San Jose specifically calls out cleaning product containers as recyclable
commonMistakes: Make sure completely empty
Leave spray nozzles on

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
San Jose collects blue carts weekly
commonMistakes: Don't crush cans
Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Steel / tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Steel is the most recycled material in the world
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove metal lids (recycle lids separately)
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: All colors of glass accepted in San Jose curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap and trash it
Don't include ceramics, mirrors, or window glass

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials
Place in or beside blue recycling cart
notes: Break down boxes so they fit in the cart
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease
Remove styrofoam inserts

materials.name: Paperboard / boxboard
instructions: Flatten
Remove plastic liner bags (trash them)
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: San Jose accepts all clean paperboard
commonMistakes: Don't include wax-coated boxes
Remove plastic liners

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: Place in blue recycling cart
No need to remove inserts or rubber bands
notes: Newspapers are high-quality recyclable fiber
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic
Don't put in green cart

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
instructions: Place in blue recycling cart
No need to remove staples or subscription cards
notes: Glossy paper is recyclable in San Jose
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Mail and office paper
instructions: Place in blue recycling cart
No need to remove staples, paper clips, or envelope windows
notes: All clean, dry paper is recyclable in San Jose
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues
Don't bag paper in plastic

materials.name: Milk / juice cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap if it has one
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Both shelf-stable (aseptic) and refrigerated cartons accepted
San Jose specifically lists cartons as recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't flatten cartons

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized
Don't puncture

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball up into a ball at least 2 inches across
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Must be clean; heavily soiled foil goes in gray cart
commonMistakes: Don't recycle heavily soiled foil
Small pieces fall through sorting screens

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT put in blue recycling cart
Take to retailer drop-off bins at Safeway, Target, or Walmart
Otherwise place in gray garbage cart
notes: Plastic bags jam San Jose's recycling machinery
Most grocery stores in San Jose have bag recycling bins
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Don't put any film plastic in the blue cart

materials.name: Styrofoam
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Not accepted in San Jose curbside recycling
notes: Styrofoam contaminates recycling streams
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart
Don't put in green cart

materials.name: Food-soiled items
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Food-soiled items contaminate recycling
Items must be clean to be recycled
notes: San Jose specifically calls out food/liquids/food-soiled items as NOT recyclable
This is a top contamination issue in the cart tagging program
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled items in blue cart
A quick rinse can save a container from the trash

materials.name: Food waste (all types)
instructions: Place ALL food waste in green organics cart
San Jose accepts all food types including meat, dairy, and bones
Include food-soiled paper (napkins, paper towels, paper plates)
California SB 1383 requires organic waste diversion
notes: San Jose's green cart program is mandated by California SB 1383
All food goes in the green cart; meat, bones, dairy, fish, everything
GreenWaste of San Jose processes organics at industrial composting facility
commonMistakes: Don't put food in the gray garbage cart; use the green cart
Don't worry about separating meat from vegetables

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in green organics cart
Large branches: cut to 4 feet or shorter
Can be mixed with food waste in the same cart
notes: San Jose's green cart accepts both food waste and yard waste together
Collected weekly by GreenWaste of San Jose
commonMistakes: Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags
Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Food-soiled paper (compostable)
instructions: Place in green organics cart
Pizza boxes, paper plates, napkins, paper towels all go in green cart
Coffee filters and tea bags go in green cart
notes: Food-soiled paper cannot be recycled but CAN be composted in San Jose
This is required under California SB 1383
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the blue recycling cart
Don't put in gray cart; it's compostable

materials.name: Fruit / fruit scraps
instructions: Place in green organics cart
All fruit and fruit scraps accepted
notes: San Jose's green cart accepts all food waste per SB 1383
commonMistakes: Don't put fruit in gray cart; compost it
Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Vegetables / vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in green organics cart
notes: All vegetables accepted in San Jose composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in gray cart; compost it

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in green organics cart
San Jose accepts ALL meat and bones
Raw and cooked meat both accepted
notes: San Jose's industrial composting facility handles meat safely
This includes raw, cooked, and spoiled meat of all types
commonMistakes: Don't put in gray cart; use the green organics cart
Don't worry about raw vs cooked; both accepted

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Solid dairy waste goes in green organics cart
Pour expired liquid dairy down drain
Rinse and recycle the container separately in blue cart
notes: San Jose's composting program accepts dairy per SB 1383
commonMistakes: Rinse containers for blue cart
Don't put dairy-soiled containers in blue cart without rinsing

materials.name: Bread and grains
instructions: Place in green organics cart
notes: All grain products accepted in San Jose composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in gray cart

materials.name: Coffee grounds / tea bags
instructions: Coffee grounds and paper filters go in green organics cart
Paper tea bags go in green cart (remove staples if metal)
notes: Coffee grounds add nitrogen to compost
commonMistakes: Check that tea bags are paper, not plastic mesh

materials.name: Eggs / eggshells
instructions: Place in green organics cart
Crush eggshells for faster breakdown
notes: Eggshells add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Snacks and candy (food portion)
instructions: The food goes in green organics cart
The wrapper goes in gray garbage cart
notes: Separate food from wrapper
commonMistakes: Don't put wrappers in green cart

materials.name: Condiments and sauces
instructions: The sauce/condiment goes in green organics cart
The bottle: rinse and put in blue recycling cart
notes: Separate container from contents
commonMistakes: Don't recycle bottles with sauce still in them

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in gray garbage cart
Do NOT compost pet waste
notes: Pet waste contains harmful pathogens
commonMistakes: Never put in green organics cart
Don't flush cat litter

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do not put in trash or recycling
Take to a San Jose Household Hazardous Waste drop-off
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries before transport
notes: Batteries cause fires in garbage trucks and at recycling facilities
San Jose HHW facility accepts batteries for free
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in gray cart
Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to San Jose HHW facility or e-waste recycling event
Best Buy accepts many electronics for free
Delete personal data before disposal
notes: California law (SB 20) prohibits e-waste in trash
San Jose holds periodic e-waste collection events
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in trash or recycling
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to San Jose Household Hazardous Waste facility
Latex paint: can also dry out with kitty litter and put in gray cart
Oil-based paint: must go to HHW
notes: San Jose HHW facility on Los Esteros Rd accepts paint for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down drains
Don't put liquid paint in gray cart

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to San Jose HHW facility
AutoZone and O'Reilly accept used oil for free
Collect in original container or sealed jug
notes: Most auto parts stores accept used oil at no charge
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains or on the ground
Don't mix with other fluids

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to MedSafe drop-off locations in San Jose
CVS and Walgreens in San Jose participate in take-back programs
If no drop-off: mix with coffee grounds, seal in bag, and place in gray cart
notes: San Jose has MedSafe permanent drop-off kiosks at multiple locations
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put loose pills in trash

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to San Jose HHW facility
LED bulbs: take to e-waste recycling
Incandescent: wrap and place in gray cart
notes: CFL and fluorescent bulbs contain mercury
Home Depot and Lowe's accept CFL bulbs for free
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL bulbs in gray cart; mercury is hazardous
Don't put any bulbs in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to San Jose HHW facility
Never pour down drains
notes: Pouring grease down the drain causes sewer blockages and sanitary sewer overflows
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drains

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to San Jose HHW facility
Never put in gray cart or blue cart
Home improvement stores may accept for exchange
notes: Pressurized containers are fire and explosion risks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in trash or recycling

materials.name: Needles / sharps
instructions: Place in FDA-cleared sharps container or heavy-duty plastic bottle
Seal and label container
Take to San Jose HHW or participating pharmacy
notes: California law prohibits loose sharps in household trash
commonMistakes: Never put loose needles in trash
Never put in recycling

materials.name: Smartphone / phone
instructions: Factory reset and remove personal data
Trade in at carrier stores, Apple, or Samsung
Take to Best Buy or e-waste recycling event
notes: Working phones can be donated
Many carriers offer trade-in credit
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data
Don't put in gray cart

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or local thrift stores
San Jose has textile recycling collection bins at various locations
Even torn or stained clothing can be recycled
notes: San Jose has multiple donation and textile recycling options
Textiles should not go in any curbside cart
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in blue recycling cart
Don't put in gray cart if donatable

materials.name: Wires and cables
instructions: Take to Best Buy or e-waste recycling
Do NOT put in blue recycling cart
Cables tangle in recycling machinery
notes: Best Buy accepts up to 3 items per household per day
commonMistakes: Never put cables in curbside carts
Tangled cables shut down sorting equipment

materials.name: Candy wrapper
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Metallized plastic film is not recyclable
notes: Candy wrappers are plastic film with metallic coating; not true aluminum
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart
Don't put in green cart

materials.name: Chip bag
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Metallized plastic is not recyclable
notes: The shiny interior is aluminum bonded to plastic
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Lined paper cups go in gray garbage cart
Plastic lids: place in blue recycling cart
Paper sleeve: place in blue recycling cart
notes: The plastic/wax lining prevents paper cup recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put lined cups in blue cart
Separate the lid and sleeve for recycling

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Bag and place in gray garbage cart
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in green organics cart
Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Receipts
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Thermal paper contains BPA; do not recycle
notes: Thermal receipts contaminate paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Bubble wrap / packing materials
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Or take plastic film to store drop-off bins
Do NOT put in blue recycling cart
notes: Plastic film jams recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Plastic utensils
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Not recyclable in San Jose
notes: Too small and lightweight for sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart
Compostable utensils go in green cart only if certified BPI-compostable

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate if in good condition: Goodwill, Half Price Books, San Jose Public Library
If damaged, recycle paper pages in blue cart
Remove hardcover bindings with glossy laminate (trash them)
notes: Donating is always better than recycling
Half Price Books has locations in San Jose
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Pizza boxes with grease/food residue go in green organics cart
Clean pizza box sections can go in blue recycling cart
notes: In San Jose, food-soiled pizza boxes are composted, not recycled
SB 1383 requires composting food-soiled paper
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy pizza boxes in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Paper towels / napkins
instructions: Place in green organics cart
Paper towels and napkins are compostable in San Jose
notes: SB 1383 requires composting food-soiled paper products
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart
Don't put in gray cart; they're compostable

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
instructions: Place in green organics cart
Compostable in San Jose's green cart program
notes: Wax/parchment paper cannot be recycled but can be composted
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a bulky item pickup with San Jose Environmental Services
Or take to a San Jose transfer station
notes: San Jose offers bulky item pickup by appointment
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Large / bulk items
instructions: Schedule bulky item pickup through San Jose 311 or online
Place at curb on scheduled day
Or take to a transfer station
notes: San Jose offers bulky item pickup by appointment
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to tire retailer (most accept old tires when you buy new)
Or take to San Jose HHW facility
notes: Illegal to dump tires; fines apply
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside cart
Don't dump illegally

materials.name: Car battery
instructions: Take to AutoZone, O'Reilly, or any auto parts store
Most stores accept free and may give core credit
Or take to San Jose HHW facility
notes: Lead-acid batteries are nearly 100% recyclable
California law requires retailers to accept old batteries
commonMistakes: Never put in gray cart; contains lead and acid
Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Mirrors
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Place in gray garbage cart
Label as BROKEN GLASS if broken
notes: Metallic coating prevents glass recycling
commonMistakes: Never put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Ceramics / pottery
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Wrap if broken
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Window glass / plate glass
instructions: Wrap carefully
Place in gray garbage cart
Label BROKEN GLASS if broken
notes: Different composition than bottle glass; contaminates recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Plastic wrap / cling film
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Not recyclable in San Jose
notes: Too thin for sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
notes: Mixed plastic; not recyclable in curbside programs
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Makeup / cosmetics
instructions: Most cosmetic containers go in gray garbage cart
Clean empty #1/#2/#5 containers may be recyclable
notes: Check brand take-back programs (MAC, Kiehl's, etc.)
commonMistakes: Small items fall through sorting screens

materials.name: Ink / toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot
Manufacturers offer mail-back programs
Best Buy also accepts
notes: Some stores give credit for returns
commonMistakes: Don't throw in gray cart
Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to San Jose HHW facility
Home Depot and Lowe's also accept for free
notes: Contains mercury; handle carefully
commonMistakes: Don't put in gray cart
Don't break them

materials.name: Snack pouches
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Multi-layer flexible packaging is not recyclable
notes: Made of bonded layers that can't be separated
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Metal hangers
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Or return to dry cleaners for reuse
notes: Wire hangers tangle in recycling equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Garden hose
instructions: Cut into short lengths and place in gray garbage cart
Or schedule bulky item pickup
notes: Hoses tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Never put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Fast food wrapper
instructions: Food-soiled fast food wrappers go in green organics cart
Clean wrappers go in blue recycling cart if plain paper
notes: SB 1383 requires composting food-soiled paper
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Small appliances
instructions: Donate if working: Goodwill, Salvation Army
If broken: take to e-waste recycling or HHW facility
Or schedule bulky item pickup
notes: Many small appliances contain recyclable metals
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Smoke detectors
instructions: Ionization type: mail back to manufacturer
Photoelectric type: take to e-waste recycling
Check the back of the unit for type
notes: Ionization smoke detectors contain small amounts of Americium-241
commonMistakes: Don't put in gray cart or blue cart

materials.name: Plastic toys
instructions: Donate if in working condition
If broken, place in gray garbage cart
notes: Mixed plastics make toys non-recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart
Donate before trashing

materials.name: Junk mail / catalogs
instructions: Place in blue recycling cart
No need to remove plastic windows from envelopes
notes: All paper mail is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't shred it
Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Aluminum baking pans
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Must be clean to recycle
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if heavily soiled with baked-on food

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in gray garbage cart
Too small to sort at recycling facility
notes: Shredded paper jams recycling equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling cart

materials.name: Empty spray paint cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Place in blue recycling cart
If not fully empty, treat as hazardous waste
notes: Completely empty aerosol cans are recyclable as metal
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized

recycle: Plastic bottles, jugs, and tubs (caps on)
compost: ALL food waste including meat, dairy, bones, and fish
Food-soiled paper (pizza boxes, paper plates, napkins, paper towels)
Coffee grounds, filters, and tea bags
trash: Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

tips: ALL food goes in the green organics cart (California SB 1383 mandate)
Food-soiled paper goes in green cart, not blue or gray
No plastic bags in any cart; take to store drop-off
Rinse containers; a quick rinse is sufficient
San Jose uses cart tagging: wrong items in your blue cart may get a tag and not be collected
2022 study found 57% of items in tagged carts were wrong; check before you toss

locations.name: San Jose Household Hazardous Waste (HHW) Drop-off
locations.address: 1608 Los Esteros Rd, San Jose, CA 95116
locations.notes: Free for Santa Clara County residents. No appointment needed. ID required.

locations.name: GreenWaste of San Jose
locations.address: 610 Los Esteros Rd, San Jose, CA 95116
locations.notes: San Jose's contracted waste hauler. Call for cart issues or to schedule bulky pickup.
